titleStmt.title: The charge of the Commons of England, against Charls Stuart, King of England, of high treason, and other high crimes, exhibited to the High Court of Justice, by John Cook Esquire, Solicitor General, appointed by the said Court, for, and on the behalf of the people of England. As it was read to him by the clerk in the said court, as soon as Mr. Solicitor General for the Kingdom had impeached him, in the name of the Commons of England, at his first araignment, Saturday, Ian. 20. 1648. Examined by the original copy. Imprimatur, Gilbert Mabbot.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE CHARGE OF THE COMMONS OF ENGLAND, Again≈øt Charls Stuart, King of England, Of High Trea≈øon, and other High Crimes, exhibited to the High Court of Ju≈øtice, By John Cook E≈øquire, Solicitor General, appointed by the ≈øaid Court, for, and on the behalf of the People of England.

As it was read to Him by the Clerk in the ≈øaid Court, as ≈øoon as Mr. Solicitor General for the Kingdom had Impeached Him, in the name of the Commons of England, at His fir≈øt Araignment, Saturday, Ian. 20. 1648.
Examined by the Original Copy. Imprimatur,
London, Printed for Rapha Harford, at the Gilt Bible in Queens-Head-Alley in Pater-no≈øter-Row. 1648.

div.head: THE Charge of the Commons of England, again≈øt CHARLS STUART, King of England, Of High Trea≈øon, and other High Crimes, exhibited to the High Court of Ju≈øtice, Saturday, Ianuary 20. 1648.
div.p: The Court being ≈øate, and the Pri≈øoner at the Bar, Mr. Cook, Solicitor General, ≈øpake thus; My Lord, In behalf of the Commons of England, and of all the people thereof, I do accu≈øe Charls Stuart, here pre≈øent, of High Trea≈øon, and High Mi≈ødemeanors: And I do, in the name of the Commons of England, de≈øire the Charge may be read unto Him, which the Clerk then read, as followeth;

THat the ≈øaid CHARLS STUART, being admitted King of England, and therein tru≈øted with a limited Power, to Govern by, and according to the Laws of the Land, and not otherwi≈øe; And by his Tru≈øt, Oath, and Office, being obliged to u≈øe the power committed to him, For the good and benefit of the People, and for the pre≈øervation of their Rights and Liberties; Yet neverthele≈øs, out of a wicked De≈øign, to erect and uphold in him≈øelf an unlimited and Tyrannicall power, to rule according to his Will,
and to overthrow the Rights and Liberties of the People; Yea, to take away, and make void the foundations thereof, and of all redre≈øs and remedy of mi≈ø-government, which by the fundamental Con≈øtitutions of this Kingdom, were re≈øerved on the Peoples behalf, in the Right and Power of frequent and ≈øucce≈øsive Parliaments, or Nationall meetings in Councell; He, the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, for accompli≈øhment of ≈øuch his De≈øigns, and for the protecting of him≈øelf and his adherents, in His and Their wicked Practi≈øes to the ≈øame Ends, hath Trayterou≈øly and maliciou≈øly levyed War again≈øt the pre≈øent Parliament, & the People therein Repre≈øented.

Particularly, upon or about the thirtieth day of Iune, in the yeer of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty and two, At Beverly, in the County of York; And upon, or about the thirtieth day of Iuly, in the yeer afore≈øaid, in the County of the City of York; And upon, or about the twenty fourth day of Augu≈øt, in the ≈øame yeer, at the County of the Town of Nottingham (when, and where He ≈øet up His Standard of War;) And al≈øo on, or about the twenty third day of October, in the ≈øame yeer, at Edg-Hill, and Keinton field, in the County of Warwick; And upon, or about the thirtieth
day of November, in the ≈øame yeer, at Brainchford, in the County of Middle≈øex: And upon, or about the thirtieth day of Augu≈øt, in the yeer of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fourty and three, at Cave≈øham-bridg, neer Reding, in the County of Berks; And upon, or about the thirtieth day of October, in the yeer la≈øt mentioned, at, or neer the City of Gloce≈øter; And upon, or about the thirtieth day of November, in the yeer la≈øt mentioned, at Newbery, in the County of Berks; And upon, or about the one and thirtieth day of Iuly, in the yeer of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fourty and four, at Cropredy-bridg, in the County of Oxon; And upon, or about the thirtieth day of September, in the yeer la≈øt mentioned, at Bodmin, and other places neer adjacent, in the County of Cornwal; And upon, or about the thirtieth day of November, in the yeer la≈øt mentioned, at Newbery afore≈øaid; And upon, or about the eighth day of Iune, in the yeer of our Lord, one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty and five, at the Town of Leice≈øter; And al≈øo, upon the fourteenth day of the ≈øame moneth, in the ≈øame yeer, at Na≈øebyfield, in the County of Northampton. At which ≈øeveral times and places, or mo≈øt of them, and at many other places in this Land, at ≈øeveral
other times, within the yeers aforementioned: And in the yeer of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fourty and ≈øix, He the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, hath cau≈øed and procured many thou≈øands of the free-people of the Nation to be ≈ølain; and by Divi≈øions, Parties, and In≈øurrections, within this Land, by inva≈øions from forraign parts, endevored and procured by Him, and by many other evil ways and means. He the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, hath not onely maintained and carryed on the ≈øaid War, both by Land and Sea, during the yeers before mentioned; but al≈øo hath renewed, or cau≈øed to be renewed, the ≈øaid War again≈øt the Parliament, and good people of this Nation, in this pre≈øent yeer, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty and eight, in the Counties of Kent, E≈ø≈øex, Surrey, Su≈ø≈øex, Middle≈øex, and many other Counties and places in England and Wales, and al≈øo by Sea; And particularly, He the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, hath for that purpo≈øe, Given Commi≈øsions to his Son, the Prince, and others, whereby, Be≈øides multitudes of other per≈øons, many ≈øuch, as were by the Parliament intru≈øted and imployed, for the ≈øafety of the Nation; being by Him or His Agents, corrupted; to the betraying of their Tru≈øt, and revolting from the Parliament, have had entertainment and commi≈øsion,
for the continuing and renewing of War and Ho≈øtility, again≈øt the ≈øaid Parliament and People, as afore≈øaid. By which cruel and unnatural Wars by Him, the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, levyed, continued, and renewed, as afore≈øaid, much Innocent blood of the Free-people of this Nation hath been ≈øpilt; many Families have been undone, the Publike Trea≈øury wa≈øted and exhau≈øted, Trade obstructed, and mi≈øerably decayed; va≈øt expence and damage to the Nation incurred, and many parts of the Land ≈øpoyled, ≈øome of them even to de≈øolation.

And for further pro≈øecution of His ≈øaid evil De≈øigns, He, the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, doth ≈øtill continue his Commi≈øsions to the ≈øaid Prince, and other Rebels and Revolters, both Engli≈øh and Forraigners; and to the Earl of Ormond, and to the Iri≈øh Rebels and Revolters, a≈ø≈øociated with him; from whom further Inva≈øions upon this Land are threatned, upon the procurement, and on the behalf of the ≈øaid Charls Stuart.

All which wicked De≈øigns, Wars, and evill practi≈øes of Him, the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, have been, and are carryed on, for the advancing and upholding of the Per≈øonal Intere≈øt of Will and Power, and pretended Prerogative to Him≈øelf and his Family, again≈øt the publike Intere≈øt, Common Right, Liberty, Ju≈øtice, and Peace

Of the People of this Nation, by, and for whom he was entru≈øted, as afore≈øaid.

By all which it appeareth, that He, the ≈øaid Charls Stuart hath been, and is the Occa≈øioner, Author, and Contriver of the ≈øaid Unnaturall, Cruell, and bloody Wars, and therein guilty of all the Trea≈øons, Murthers, Rapines, Burnings, Spoiles, De≈øolations, Damage and Mi≈øchief to this Nation, acted or committed in the ≈øaid Wars, or occa≈øioned thereby.

And the ≈øaid Iohn Cook, by Prote≈øtation (≈øaving on the behalf of the People of England, the liberty of Exhibiting at any time hereafter, any other Charge again≈øt the ≈øaid Charls Stuart; and al≈øo of replying to the An≈øwers which the ≈øaid Charls Stuart ≈øhall make to the Premi≈øes, or any of them, or any other Charge that ≈øhall be ≈øo Exhibited) doth, for the ≈øaid Trea≈øons and Crimes, on the behalf of the ≈øaid People of England, Impeach the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, as a Tyrant, Traytor, Murtherer, and a publike, and Implacable Enemy to the Common-wealth of England: And pray, That the ≈øaid Charls Stuart, King of England, may be put to an≈øwer All and Every the
‚Ä¢ remi≈øes, That ≈øuch Proceedings, Examinations, ‚Ä¢ ryals, Sentence, and Iudgment may be thereupon had, or ≈øhall be agreeable to Ju≈øtice.
